column1: Maricopa is a city in the Gila River Valley in Arizona. With an estimated 52
column3: Maricopa forms part of the Phoenix metropolitan area.

column1: Maricopa has had three locations over the years: Maricopa Wells
column2: Maricopaville and Maricopa Junction; the latter gradually became known as Maricopa. It started as an oasis around a series of watering holes eight miles north of present-day Maricopa
column3: and about a mile west of Pima Butte. European-American traders and travelers called it Maricopa Wells. Several of Arizona's rivers
column6: Vekol and Santa Rosa provided this oasis in the desert with an ample supply of water during this period of time.

column2: Maricopa Wells was one of the most important relay stations along the San Antonio-San Diego Mail Line and the later more famous Butterfield Overland Mail Route.  Although little remains of this once bustling community
column3: it played an important part in the progress and development of the Southwest. It was one of the best-known spots in Arizona during this period of time because it had a reliable source of water
column4: and offered an abundant supply of food. The peaceful Pima and Maricopa farmers who lived and farmed nearby sold supplies to travelers and migrants.

column1: The most prosperous period of time for Maricopa Wells was in the 1870s. During this time the trading center at the Wells provided water and food for not only the east–west travelers
column2: but those who traveled to the north to Phoenix. Fairly good roads had been built by James A. Moore
column5: and the Wells was a constant hubbub of activity.

column1: Maricopaville developed south and west of the Wells
column2: following construction of a railroad line from this terminus to Phoenix. In 1879
column3: the Southern Pacific Railroad was in the process of building a railroad line from Yuma to Tucson
column4: and a second railroad line was to be built from Maricopaville
column5: wrapping around the western edge of South Mountain into Phoenix. With the railroad
column6: Maricopaville took on the appearance of a gold rush California boom town
column7: as men worked day and night building hotels
column12: etc.  One newspaper of the time reckoned that with its thousands of people and good location
column13: Maricopaville would be an ideal choice for the location of the state capital.

column1: But the railroad never built the anticipated line from Maricopaville into Phoenix.  Tempe also wanted to be on the railroad line and lobbied the territorial government to gain a stop. Officials agreed. The settlement known as Maricopaville was essentially rebuilt three miles to the east (to the present location of Maricopa) in the early 1880s

column1: Maricopa is primarily served by Arizona State Route 347
column2: a north–south highway that connects to Interstate 10
column4: as well as Arizona State Route 84 11 miles south of Maricopa. State Route 84 then ends at Interstate 8 approximately 6 miles west of State Route 347. Within Maricopa
column5: State Route 347 is John Wayne Parkway. As it leaves the city for the Gila River Indian Community to the north or the Ak-Chin Indian Community to the south
column6: the road changes names to Maricopa Road. A portion of old State Route 347 within Maricopa also exists as Maricopa Road.Maricopa is also served by Arizona State Route 238
column7: which connects Maricopa to the town of Mobile
column8: which is incorporated into the city of Goodyear. Past Mobile
column9: State Route 238 becomes a county route that connects to Arizona State Route 85 in Gila Bend. State Route 238 and Mobile Road designations are used interchangeably. State Route 238 ends at State Route 347
column10: and continues east as Smith-Enke Road
column11: a major east–west corridor for the city of Maricopa. Maricopa-Casa Grande Highway also makes up a major corridor for the city
column12: connecting it to the city of Casa Grande. This road parallels the Union Pacific Railroad at a diagonal
column13: ultimately becoming Plainview Street within Maricopa and Cottonwood Lane in Casa Grande.

column1: Maricopa is located on a Union Pacific Railroad line. The city is currently the closest stop to Phoenix served by Amtrak's Sunset Limited and Texas Eagle trains. The Maricopa depot opened in 2001
column2: originally in a converted passenger rail car but now in a metal building.

Water: Global Water (Santa Cruz Water Company
The City of Maricopa operates the City Of Maricopa Express Transit (COMET)

Maricopa is governed by a Council-Manager form of government. This type of government structure combines the political leadership of elected officials with the managerial experience of an appointed professional manager. The City Council and City Manager work as partners to direct and guide local government.

The Maricopa City Council consists of the Mayor and six City Council members. The Mayor is elected to serve a four-year term and the City Council members are elected to serve four-year terms on a rotating basis. City Council meetings are held on the first and third Tuesdays of the month.
There are 10 citizen advisory groups that guide the Maricopa City Council on a myriad of activity. They are the Board of Adjustment
column8: Public Safety Personnel Retirement System Board
column9: Transportation Advisory Committee and the Youth Council. Selection to these groups is by City Council action.

column1: The City is organized into nine departments: the City Manager's Office
column8: Human Services and the Police Department. More than 250 individuals work for the municipality.
